description:
Bat sapovirus TLC58/HK is a species of virus belonging to the genus Sapovirus, which is a part of the family Caliciviridae. Sapoviruses are non-enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses that primarily infect the gastrointestinal tract of various mammalian hosts, including humans and bats.

The TLC58/HK strain of bat sapovirus was first isolated from a bat in Hong Kong, China. Genetic analysis has shown that this virus is closely related to other sapovirus strains found in bats, suggesting that bats may serve as a natural reservoir for these viruses.

Sapoviruses, including the bat sapovirus TLC58/HK, are known to cause acute gastroenteritis in their hosts, with symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. However, the full extent of the pathogenicity and host range of this specific bat sapovirus strain is still under investigation.

Further research is needed to better understand the epidemiology, transmission dynamics, and potential public health implications of this and other bat-borne sapovirus strains.
